CANADA'S government regularly steps in when major artworks are sold to foreigners. Now a 1905 Ford Model C is caught up in the country's control over cultural property exports.

The car was made by Ford Motor of Canada in its first year of operation, in what is now Windsor, Ontario. For 29 years, the Model C has been on loan to the Canadian Transportation Museum in nearby Essex.

Because the car is a direct link to the beginning of what became Windsor's dominant industry, it has been an important part of the museum. Mickey Moulder, the museum's co-chairman, said the institution did not know the car was a protected icon. ''It was a surprise,'' said Mr. Moulder, a retired manager for Ford Canada. ''We didn't know it had anything to do with culture.''

The Model C's newfound status followed the recent death of the car's 92-year-old owner, Ted Dudley. Mr. Moulder said the museum could not match a $75,000 offer for the car that Mr. Dudley's estate received from a collector in San Francisco.

After The Windsor Star newspaper reported that the car was moving on this summer, the Canadian government took notice and said the Ford could not leave Canada without a cultural property export permit.

Mr. Moulder said that he had never heard of that requirement and added that vintage cars regularly roll out of Canada without permits. But Len Westerberg, a spokesman for the Department of Canadian Heritage, said any vehicle more than 50 years old with a value of more than 3,000 Canadian dollars needed an export permit.

If the estate decides to proceed with the sale and applies for a permit, a number of steps can occur. Most likely, the government will give Canadians two months to four months to produce a matching offer that would keep the car in the country. Ford Canada owns the only other known Canadian-made Model C.
